metadata.titleEn: ILSF-RT (2015-2020)：Global satellite-based precipitation fusion-calibration product considering four essential elements
metadata.description: This dataset is a global satellite-based precipitation fusion-calibration product with a spatial-temporal resolution of 25km/3hr, independently developed by Dr. Yong Bin's team at Hohai University. The original data sources include the Global Precipitation Measurement (GPM) IMERG-Early satellite precipitation estimates and ground observation from Climate Prediction Center (CPC). The development process involved establishing error correction models based on the rainfall intensity from IMERG-Early and CPC datasets for different terrains, climatic zones, and seasons during the period of 2010-2014. Subsequently, the models were applied to perform real-time error correction for IMERG-Early (25km/1day, 60°N-60°S) from 2015-2020 years incorporating by terrain information, and climatic zone files. Further steps involved downscaling and resampling to achieve a spatial-temporal resolution of 25km/3hr. Finally, for the high-latitude region (90°N-60°N) and the China region (15°N-59°N, 70°E-140°E), ERA5 data and fusion precipitation data based on random forest were incorporated, respectively. The experiment result shows that the BIAS of the ILSF-RT precipitation dataset is less than 15% at a global scale. The development of the algorithm and the production of this dataset are of significant importance in enhancing the accuracy of mainstream real-time satellite-based precipitation products. It also greatly enhances the potential application of real-time satellite-based precipitation products in natural disaster forecasting and early warning.
metadata.instructions:
File Naming: The globally integrated and calibrated satellite precipitation fusion product, considering the key four elements, is stored in the NetCDF format. The file is named "ILSF-RT_Precipitation_Estimates_25km_V001_yyyymmdd-hhH.nc4". Here, "ILSF-RT" represents the algorithm name, "Precipitation_Estimates" indicates the element name for rainfall estimation, "25km" denotes the spatial resolution, "V001" signifies the version number of the algorithm developed by the research team. "yyyy" represents the year, "mm" represents the month, "dd" represents the day, and "hhH" represents the hour. For example, "ILSF-RT_Precipitation_Estimates_25km_V001_20150101-00H.nc4" represents a NetCDF file describing the 3-hour cumulative rainfall estimates for the global coverage from 0:00 to the following two hours on the first day of 2015.

Data Read Method: All NetCDF files in this dataset can be opened directly using programming languages or corresponding software such as Matlab and HDF Explorer. In addition to other information, the main content of these files consists of numerical representations of global rainfall estimates. If visual representation is desired, the files can be opened using ArcGIS, which will display the graphical representation of the NetCDF files.

background: High-accuracy near-real-time satellite precipitation estimates (SPEs) provide an opportunity for hydrometeorologists to improve the forecasting of extreme events, such as flood, landslide, tropical cyclone, and other extreme events, at the large scale. However, the currently operational near-real-time SPEs still have larger errors and uncertainties.

A comprehensive investigation with regard to the relationships between retrieval errors and four factors (i.e., topography, seasonality, climate type, and rain rate) is still lacking. By analyzing the error components of GPM-based passive microwave (PMW) and infrared sensors, for the first time, we comprehensively revealed the dependency of retrieval errors of satellite precipitation on the topography, season, and climate type over mainland China. Furthermore, a power function relationship between retrieval errors and logarithm of rain rates was subsequently proposed in the extended study. In practice, many previous literatures have proposed various correction methods to improve the accuracy of the near-real-time SPPs for enhancing their potentials in natural hazard forecasting. However, these correction methods suffer from different defects: 1) some methods strongly depend on the ground observations in real-time and their effectiveness is also closely related to the observed accuracy; 2) some methods used the satellite-derived soil moisture products to correct SPEs in real-time, but these ways may introduce new error sources and degrade the retrieval quality of original SPPs; 3) others only selected single or few factors but neglected some crucial ones associated with retrieval errors, leading to the fundamental algorithmic defects in establishing the EAMs; and 4) some real-time error correction methods work for only reducing systematic error, but the major error component of current satellite products is random error. Merging different precipitation products is an effective way to enhance the quality of SPPs. However, it cannot correct SPEs in real-time.

Our previous studies have found that the errors of the satellite-based precipitation estimates are closely related to four crucial factors, i.e., seasonality, topography, climate type, and rain rate. However, the comprehensive relationships between satellite retrieval errors and these four factors are still not investigated, and the expected EAM was also not established. Based on the SPF relationships adaptive for 16 different categories, we proposed a novel bias adjustment method to correct the hourly GSMaP-NRT estimates in real-time.

With the rapid development of remote sensing technique in the past 20 years, the retrieval information from various satellite sensors becomes a reliable data source of obtaining areal precipitation estimates over large scales and even globe. Although the satellite-based precipitation estimates are indirect, the high frequency and broad coverage make them uniquely complementary to conventional rain gauge networks and weather radars. Also, the satellite-based precipitation estimates provide an opportunity for both hydrologists and meteorologists to improve the forecasting of extreme events, such as flood warning, landslide detection, typhoon monitoring, and drought diagnosis, at the large scale. In practice, the near-real-time satellite precipitation products (SPPs) are more appropriate for these hydrometeorological predictions relative to post-real-time research quality SPPs. However, the near-real-time SPPs normally have larger errors and uncertainties than the post-real-time products. Therefore, it is important to develop effective error correction methods for further improving the data accuracy of mainstream SPPs in real-time, which will significantly enhance their application potentials especially for natural hazard warning. The scientific understanding of error features of satellite precipitation estimates (SPEs) is essential to establish the error adjustment model (EAM) in correction methods.
research objective: In this study, we found that there exists a clear relationship of spatial plane function (SPF) between retrieval errors of SPEs and four crucial factors including topography, seasonality, climate type, and rain rate.

This study primarily aims at establishing an effective EAM to correct the hourly near-real-time global satellite mapping of precipitation (GSMaP-NRT) by analyzing the function relationships between satellite retrieval errors and multiple factors in detail. Consequently, here we proposed a novel real-time error adjustment method that considers four impacting factors to precipitation errors to correct for the hourly GSMaP-NRT precipitation estimates in real-time.

This study attempts to comprehensively consider four crucial factors associated with retrieval errors and effectively correct the near-real-time multi-SPEs by the EAM derived from historical satellite–gauge data pairs. In this study, we systematically investigated the relationships between retrieval errors of SPEs and four crucial factors including topography, seasonality, climate type, and rain rate over mainland China.
challenges: However, these schemes might introduce the new error sources due to large errors inherent in satellite soil moisture. Despite that the new method shows great advantages for error corrections in real-time relative to the existing real-time error correction methods, it also cannot reduce missed precipitation and its limited improvements in reducing false errors. In addition, this method has another common problem also inherent in the existing algorithms, that is, underestimating the rainfall volume in the rain rates over 1 mm hr−1.
However, the results of bias score show that the current method seems unsuitable to adjust the rainfall events with higher rain rates (>= 1m mh r −1), which needs to be further improved.
methods: In our study, the hourly GSMaP-NRT was first corrected by the proposed method to produce a set of new precipitation product ILSF-RT, which was then intercompared with both GSMaP-NRT and GSMaP-Gauge-NRT to validate the new approach.

In the new correction method, we design a better expression for topography using the standard deviation of elevation [SDE, see Fig. 1(b)] to substitute the original average elevation. The retrieval errors (E) can be simply calculated by satellite rain rate (S) minus ground observations (G). The new method primarily adopts the ILS method to solve the parameter estimates of the EAMs that consider four factors, and then the errors and biases of GSMaP-NRT are reduced based on (4) and (6). Finally, the ILSF-RT product was comprehensively intercompared with GSMaP-NRT and GSMaP-Gauge-NRT over mainland China for validation using various evaluation indices. To quantify the performance of the new proposed method, we used seven statistical indices including correlation coefficient (CC), root mean squared error (RMSE), normalized root mean squared error (NRMSE), relative bias (RBIAS), and three types of error components (hit bias, miss bias, and false bias).
dataset: Two GPM-based hourly SPEs, including GSMaP-NRT and GSMaP-Gauge-NRT, were used in this study.

An observation network of over 30 000 conventional rain gauges covering mainland China [see Fig. 1(a)] was used to calibrate and validate the EAMs in the new method. Here, we selected one complete year of 2015 with GSMaP-NRT and ground observations for calibration and two years of three datasets (two near-real-time GSMaP products and gauged observations), from April 2017 to March 2019, for validation, considering the GSMaP-Gauge-NRT V7 data available starting from April 2017.
findings: Generally speaking, ILSF-RT product performs the best among three products in terms of RMSE and RBIAS scores (see Table II), meaning that the new proposed method is effective in reducing the rainfall errors of the original GSMaP-NRT. Meanwhile, the new method effectively reduces the errors of GSMaP-NRT associated with seasonality and climate (see Figs. 4 and 5). In particular, this new proposed method evidently improves the data quality over arid areas and cold seasons (spring and winter), which improves the application potentials of GSMaP-NRT in such areas where no ground observations are not available. Overall, the new method proposed in this study considers the relationships between retrieval errors and four crucial factors, and the verification results have proved the effectiveness in reducing the retrieval errors.

The results show that the proposed method can effectively reduce the retrieval errors of GSMaP-NRT for various terrains and rain rates over different seasons and climate-type areas. The new ILSF-RT even exhibits a general improvement over the GSMaP-Gauge-NRT estimates. One important merit of the new method is that it can perform rather well in validation even when not much historical data were applied as training samples in calibration. Overall, we can conclude that the new proposed method can substantially improve the data accuracy of hourly GSMaP-NRT estimates and even perform better than the gauged adjustment scheme used in GSMaP-Gauge-NRT. The spatial analyses from Fig. 6 demonstrate that the new method effectively reduces the retrieval errors of GSMaP-NRT for various terrains and over different seasons and climate areas and ILSF-RT generally exhibits the best performance among three evaluation products.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'spatial plane function (SPF)' in the correction of satellite precipitation data?
Definition.Answer: Spatial plane function (SPF) refers to the mathematical relationship established between the retrieval errors of satellite precipitation estimates and four critical factors: topography, seasonality, climate type, and rain rate. The SPF is used to understand how these factors influence errors and to formulate a correction method to improve the accuracy of the satellite data.

Comparison.Question: How do data collection methods utilizing ground observations compare to those using satellite-based precipitation estimates in terms of accuracy and error adjustment?
Comparison.Answer: Ground observations, such as rain gauge networks, provide direct measurements and are often used for calibrating and validating satellite-based precipitation estimates. Satellite estimates, like those from GSMaP-NRT, offer broad coverage and high frequency but are indirect and have larger errors. The new correction methods aim to reduce these errors by considering factors such as topography and climate type, which may not be accounted for in ground observations alone.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in handling retrieval errors when using satellite-based soil moisture products versus traditional satellite precipitation products?
Comparison.Answer: Using satellite-based soil moisture products introduces new error sources due to large inherent errors, potentially degrading retrieval quality. Traditional satellite precipitation products focus on correcting systematic errors, but the major component is random error. The new methods described aim to address these errors by considering multiple factors like seasonality and climate type, which are not typically addressed in soil moisture product corrections.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do merging precipitation products differ from real-time correction methods in improving satellite precipitation estimates?
Comparison.Answer: Merging precipitation products can enhance the overall quality but does not adjust errors in real-time. Real-time correction methods, such as those proposed with ILSF-RT, specifically target reducing retrieval errors by considering multiple factors like topography and climate type. These methods provide immediate improvements in data accuracy, which is crucial for applications like natural hazard forecasting.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of varying topographical features, climate types, and seasonal variations enhance the accuracy of satellite precipitation estimates?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration can enhance accuracy by establishing a relationship between retrieval errors and these factors. By analyzing these relationships, effective error adjustment models can be developed, which consider the influence of topography, seasonality, climate type, and rain rate on satellite precipitation estimates.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways could the development of real-time error correction methods impact the application of satellite precipitation products in natural hazard forecasting?
Interpretation.Answer: Real-time error correction methods could significantly improve the accuracy of satellite precipitation products, making them more reliable for natural hazard forecasting. By reducing errors associated with seasonality, topography, and climate, these methods can enhance the potential for early warning systems for events like floods and landslides, especially in regions with limited ground observations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors lead to errors in satellite precipitation estimates, particularly in diverse topographic and climatic regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Errors in satellite precipitation estimates are closely related to four crucial factors: topography, seasonality, climate type, and rain rate. These factors influence the retrieval errors of satellite precipitation, necessitating comprehensive investigation and bias adjustment methods to correct these errors in real-time.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do existing real-time error correction methods for satellite precipitation products struggle with high rain rates?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Existing real-time error correction methods often struggle with high rain rates because they primarily address systematic errors and may introduce new error sources. These methods tend to underestimate rainfall volume for rain rates over 1 mm/hr and have limited effectiveness in reducing missed precipitation and false errors.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the integration of various precipitation datasets to be challenging in real-time applications?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The integration of various precipitation datasets in real-time is challenging due to the inherent large errors and uncertainties in satellite-derived products. Combining datasets requires addressing these errors, often related to retrieval inaccuracies influenced by factors such as topography, seasonality, climate type, and rain rate, which complicates real-time corrections.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts on satellite precipitation product accuracy when merging data from various sources such as satellite observations and ground-based measurements?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Merging different precipitation products is an effective way to enhance the quality of satellite precipitation products (SPPs). This approach can help correct errors in real-time, significantly improving the accuracy and reducing the biases of the original satellite-based estimates. It can also improve the data quality over areas with no ground observations, such as arid regions and during cold seasons.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using a novel error adjustment method on the performance of satellite precipitation products in regions with sparse ground observation networks?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a novel error adjustment method can significantly improve the performance of satellite precipitation products in regions with sparse ground observation networks. Such methods effectively reduce retrieval errors associated with varying terrains, seasons, and climate types, thus enhancing the potential application of satellite data in areas where traditional ground observations are lacking.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to analyze the relationship between satellite retrieval errors and factors such as topography, seasonality, climate type, and rain rate?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Analyzing these relationships is crucial because it allows for the development of a comprehensive error adjustment model that can effectively correct satellite precipitation estimates, thereby improving their accuracy and making them more useful for hydrometeorological predictions and natural hazard forecasting.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can one systematically investigate the relationships between satellite precipitation retrieval errors and factors like topography, seasonality, and climate type to improve data accuracy?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: One approach is to analyze the error components of satellite-based precipitation estimates, such as those from GPM-based passive microwave and infrared sensors, by establishing a spatial plane function (SPF) that correlates retrieval errors with topography, season, and climate type. This includes using a power function to propose a bias adjustment method, which aims to correct errors in near-real-time satellite precipitation products by considering these crucial factors over a specified region such as mainland China.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in creating a high-resolution satellite precipitation dataset that combines multiple data sources, and how is accuracy validated?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The process involves developing an error correction model using historical data from satellite estimates and ground observations to adjust for errors related to topography, seasonality, climate type, and rain rate. This model is applied to near-real-time satellite data, such as the GSMaP-NRT, to produce a corrected dataset. Validation is done by comparing the new dataset with both the original and gauge-adjusted satellite data using statistical indices like RMSE and RBIAS, and by assessing performance across different terrains and climate areas.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods can be employed to integrate ground-based observations with satellite data to enhance the accuracy of satellite precipitation products?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A method involves merging satellite-based precipitation estimates with ground-based observations, such as those from an observation network of over 30,000 rain gauges. This integration requires establishing error adjustment models (EAMs) that consider crucial factors such as topography and seasonality, and applying these models to correct satellite data in real-time. The effectiveness of this integration can be validated by comparing the corrected data against both ground observations and existing satellite products.

Enablement.Question: What data correction methods enable the improvement of near-real-time satellite precipitation estimates in areas with varying topography and climate types?
Enablement.Answer: Data correction methods that consider relationships between retrieval errors and factors such as topography, seasonality, climate type, and rain rate can enable the improvement of near-real-time satellite precipitation estimates. Techniques like the Integrated Least Squares (ILS) method are utilized to adjust errors and biases in satellite data, effectively reducing retrieval errors in varying conditions.

Enablement.Question: What technological and methodological advancements enable the reduction of errors in satellite precipitation data for extreme weather event forecasting?
Enablement.Answer: Technological and methodological advancements such as the development of error adjustment models and the use of spatial plane function relationships enable the reduction of errors in satellite precipitation data. These advancements allow for more accurate forecasting of extreme weather events by addressing the dependency of retrieval errors on various factors like topography, season, and climate.

Expectation.Question: Why might a comprehensive error correction method for satellite precipitation estimates involve four factors like topography, seasonality, climate type, and rain rate?
Expectation.Answer: A comprehensive error correction method that involves factors such as topography, seasonality, climate type, and rain rate is crucial because these elements are closely linked to the retrieval errors of satellite precipitation estimates. Understanding the relationships between these factors and the errors allows for more precise correction models, ultimately enhancing the accuracy of satellite precipitation data, especially in real-time applications.

Expectation.Question: What are some anticipated challenges when using real-time error correction methods for satellite precipitation products?
Expectation.Answer: Some anticipated challenges with real-time error correction methods for satellite precipitation products include the introduction of new error sources due to the large inherent errors in satellite soil moisture, limited improvements in reducing false errors, and underestimating rainfall volumes for higher rain rates. These challenges highlight the ongoing need to refine correction algorithms to address both systematic and random errors effectively.

Judgmental.Question: How do the current data collection methods for satellite precipitation estimates address errors related to topography and climate type?
Judgmental.Answer: The current data collection methods attempt to address errors related to topography and climate type by establishing a relationship between retrieval errors and four key factors: topography, seasonality, climate type, and rain rate. A novel bias adjustment method is proposed to correct hourly estimates by analyzing these relationships in detail, resulting in improvements over arid areas and cold seasons.

Judgmental.Question: What are the challenges in integrating ground-based and satellite-derived precipitation data for creating a reliable dataset?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating ground-based and satellite-derived precipitation data faces challenges such as introducing new error sources due to large inherent errors in satellite soil moisture and the underestimation of rainfall volumes over certain rain rates. Additionally, real-time correction methods often only reduce systematic errors, while random errors remain a significant challenge.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways can future datasets improve by considering the limitations of current satellite soil moisture correction methods?
Judgmental.Answer: Future datasets can improve by addressing the limitations of current satellite soil moisture correction methods by developing algorithms that account for the comprehensive relationships between retrieval errors and crucial factors such as topography and climate. They can also incorporate advanced techniques to better handle missed precipitation and refine error sources, ultimately enhancing the accuracy and applicability of satellite precipitation products.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the correction of satellite precipitation errors can be achieved in real-time given the complexity of factors like topography and climate.
Assertion.Answer: The correction of satellite precipitation errors in real-time is achieved by establishing an error adjustment model (EAM) that considers crucial factors such as topography, seasonality, climate type, and rain rate. By analyzing the relationships between these factors and the retrieval errors, the model can adjust the errors effectively using methods like an ILS approach for parameter estimation, which can be applied in real-time.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of why merging different precipitation products is considered effective if it can't correct errors in real-time.
Assertion.Answer: Merging different precipitation products is considered effective because it enhances the overall quality of satellite precipitation products by combining the strengths of various datasets. Although it may not correct errors in real-time, it helps to improve the accuracy and reliability of the datasets by mitigating systematic errors and providing a more comprehensive data set that can be used for further analysis and correction.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection methods and techniques used to develop a global satellite precipitation dataset with high spatiotemporal resolution.
Request/Directive.Answer: The dataset is developed by first utilizing IMERG-Early and CPC data from 2010-2014 to establish an error correction model based on rain intensity across different terrains, climate zones, and seasons. This model is then applied in real-time to correct IMERG-Early data from 2015-2020, resulting in a global corrected satellite precipitation dataset with a spatial resolution of 50km/1day. Further downscaling and resampling to 25km/3hr are conducted, incorporating ERA5 data and random forest-based precipitation data in specific regions to enhance resolution.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges involved in correcting satellite precipitation estimates in real-time, focusing on the factors affecting retrieval errors.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in real-time correction of satellite precipitation estimates include the introduction of new error sources through satellite-derived soil moisture products, the dependency on real-time ground observations, and the fundamental algorithmic defects by neglecting crucial factors related to retrieval errors. Current methods may fail to correct for random errors, which are the major component, and struggle with high rain rate events. The relationship between retrieval errors and topography, seasonality, climate type, and rain rate needs detailed analysis to establish effective error adjustment models.
